Roses Aftercare: Will you be hitting the club or the tub?

26/04/2023

Emily Warner (she/her) helps you prepare for unwinding after Roses 2023

Image by Elisha Terada

By Orla McAndrew

So, Roses is over. Youâ€™ve run 10km or won a netball match or scored the winning goal in football; well done! After such a busy weekend of adrenaline, excitement and maybe some nerves, itâ€™s time for a post-Roses celebration. Iâ€™ve got a whole host of suggestions here, for every kind of athlete (or spectator) looking for the best way to unwind.

Of course, the best place to start is the Official Roses Afterparty on April 30, 9.30pm onwards. Winners, losers and everyone in between will be gathering in Revs for one of the biggest socials of the year. Come along for drinks, great music and, I was going to say a night you wonâ€™t forget but that might not be true. This club night promises to be a fun, fast-paced highlight of the social calendar; not one youâ€™ll want to miss out on.

If youâ€™re up for more after that (and not already in bed) York is home to a range of great nightclubs. You could head down to Flares (open Thursdays to Fridays) for some classic throwbacks which will have you dancing until the early hours. Or, check out Kuda (open Mondays, Tuesday, Fridays and Saturdays), the king of nightclubs, with three different rooms that suit any kind of party animal. Salvos is perfect if you want to get lost in the crowd and sway to the music without a care in the world, surrounded by smoke and dancers (open on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays).

Maybe youâ€™re not a night owl though, or dancing for hours after running around a sports pitch isnâ€™t your idea of relaxation. Donâ€™t worry, there are plenty of options for you too (more than just taking a lukewarm shower in a shared bathroom, to the music of geese squawking). Harrogate, which is just a short train ride away from York, is renowned for its spa waters and boasts a plethora of Turkish baths and spas - now thatâ€™s more like it. Their Turkish Baths are a restored version of the popular Victorian Turkish Baths. The Baths' Moorish design with Islamic arches and screens, walls of vibrant glazed brickwork, the arabesque painted ceilings and terrazzo floors all add to its historic elegant features; rest and rejuvenation almost emanates from the walls. Add a massage too and ease those aching muscles after the build-up to and exertion of Roses. You deserve it.

If something closer to home strikes your fancy, there is plenty to do in York (and no risk of another train strike interrupting your plans). There are several cinemas to choose from, including City Screen Picturehouse and Vue. Spending a couple of hours in a comfortable chair, with an inordinate amount of popcorn and no obligation to talk sounds like heaven. Itâ€™s dark enough that you can even have a little cry about losing your match, and then blame it on the movie afterwards. Or try your hand at bowling for some light-hearted competition. You can have some fun without any pressure to win (unless you have an extremely competitive friend, in which case, drop them - nobody is actually good at bowling).

After youâ€™ve done all that, you are probably feeling a bit peckish. York has many, almost too many, places to eat, drink and chat; if you want some more recommendations you can read Orla McAndrewâ€™s article â€˜A Visitorâ€™s Guide to Yorkâ€™ but I would recommend a casual stroll through the City Centre. It is easy to follow your nose to the nearest restaurant and Iâ€™ve never had a bad meal in York.

Of course, in addition to these activities, every sport comes with its own kind of aftercare, whether that is yoga (the Yoga Society always has room for one more), stretching, a massage or rest. Make sure to stay hydrated, look after your body and take a moment to enjoy the feeling of accomplishment that Roses brings. Regardless of whether you won or lost, every single participant deserves to feel proud of themselves. You just did something amazing!
